div1.p: White describes the use of yellow fever serum in one of his patients who subsequently died.

div1.head: Letter from R. O. White to F. E. Pettman, April 8, 1923
div1.p:
COPY
GOLD COAST HARBOURS
Cape Coast, April 8th, 1923. Dear Doctor Pettman:

Many thanks for your promptness and kindness in sending the
serum. You will see from attached report how unavailing it was. Indeed
it is difficult not to believe that the use of it hastened the end, so
immediate was the unfavorable reaction. He had black vomit within three
minutes of the completion of the injection, which I hope and trust, is
clear proof that the case was one of yellow fever from the start.

I based my diagnosis on a very high polymorph increase -
indeed it was difficult to find any other kind of white cellanuria, almost
complete, the appearance of a small quantity of black stained mucous which
he brought up on the afternoon of the 5th., later albuminuria about 25%,
and the degree of prostation which was not accounted for by his temperature
or symptoms. Please let me have your candid opinion.

COPY
Health Office,
Seccondee
January 15th. 1923. Case H. 2
No. 398/23.
Circular Letter
TO ALL EMPLOYERS OF NATIVE LABOUR IN SECCONDEE:-

Please note
1. A. Krooboy from here died recently in Saltpond shortly after
his arrival there from this place, with symptoms very suspicious
of Yellow Fever.
2. It is important that all cases of sickness (even if apparently
trivial), or absence from work amongst your native labour should be
enquired into.
3. Any case of sickness should be sent to a doctor as soon as possible
for examination.
4. etc. etc.
